importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Ali Danial Hemani was indicted in 2023 on a count of violating the federal guns-and-drugs law after the FBI found a 9mm pistol, marijuana, and cocaine at his family home.
A landmark Supreme Court decision in 2022 made it easier for Americans to carry handguns in public and set a precedent requiring gun prohibitions to have historical roots.

Qasem Soleimani, an Iranian official killed in a US drone strike, is referenced in connection to claims that Hemani traveled to Iran to celebrate his life, which is part of the government's appeal argument.
Hunter Biden was convicted in 2024 of the same federal law, later pardoned by President Joe Biden during his final days in office.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Supreme Court will likely hear arguments in the Hemani case next year and issue a decision by the end of June 2026.

keyTakeAways: The Supreme Court has agreed to review a federal law that prohibits certain drug users from possessing guns, specifically focusing on habitual marijuana users.

The case centers on Ali Danial Hemani, a dual U.S.-Pakistan citizen, who was indicted in 2023 for possessing a firearm and controlled substances at his home, with the prosecution based on his habitual marijuana use.
A federal district court previously dismissed the charge, citing a 2022 Supreme Court ruling that requires gun prohibitions to have historical roots and be closely tied to past laws.
The 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the district court’s decision, ruling that the law cannot apply to habitual drug users, only to those under the influence at the time of arrest.
The Trump administration appealed, arguing that habitual drug users pose a danger to public safety, especially during police encounters while impaired.

The DOJ alleged that Hemani was involved in fraud linked to the Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps and traveled to Iran to celebrate the death of Qasem Soleimani in 2020, though these claims were not independently verified.

Hemani’s legal team argued that the historical basis for the law is weak and pointed out that nearly half of U.S. states have legalized recreational marijuana, suggesting a significant overlap between legal marijuana use and gun ownership.
The case is notable because President Joe Biden’s son, Hunter Biden, was previously convicted under the same law and later pardoned by Biden.
This case is one of two significant gun-related rulings the Supreme Court is currently considering, including a separate case on whether states may bar guns on private property without consent.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Supreme Court has agreed to review a federal law that bans certain habitual drug users from possessing firearms, with the case centered on Ali Danial Hemani, a U.S.-Pakistan dual citizen indicted in 2023 for possessing a firearm and controlled substances. A lower court dismissed the charge, citing a 2022 Supreme Court precedent requiring gun prohibitions to have historical roots. The Trump administration appealed, arguing that habitual drug users pose a danger to public safety, especially during police encounters while impaired, and cited allegations involving Iran and fraud. Hemani’s legal team challenged the historical basis of the law and highlighted the widespread legalization of marijuana in U.S. states. The case is notable for its potential to redefine the scope of the Second Amendment and for involving President Joe Biden’s son, Hunter Biden, who was previously convicted under the same law. The Supreme Court is expected to issue a decision by the end of June 2026, making this a pivotal moment in U.S. gun rights and drug policy law.
title: Justices agree to review federal law banning drug users from possessing guns
